Award.AwardTitle: Developing paleomagnetic chronologies of, and paleogeomagnetic understanding from, IODP sites U1486 and U1489 in the western Pacific warm pool.
Award.AbstractNarration: Observations of Earth's magnetic field over timescales from thousands to millions of years are important for understanding how the geodynamo operates and shields the Earth from harmful incoming solar radiation. As ocean sediments accumulate on the seafloor they record the ambient magnetic field and thereby provide an important record of past geomagnetic behavior. Many of the existing high quality records that span the last 2-3 million years are from North Atlantic Ocean sediments, which represents a narrow, and maybe even unique, magneto-geographical range. To properly represent the global field and its variability requires records from other regions of the globe for the same time period. Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP) Expedition 363 to the West Pacific Warm Pool drilled nine equatorial sites in the Indian and Pacific Oceans and recovered a total of 7km of ocean sediment core. Preliminary measurements suggest two of these sites, U1486 and U1489, contain high quality magnetic records that can be used to investigate and understand the behavior of Earth's magnetic field over the last 1.25 (U1486) and 5 (U1489) million years. This project seeks to measure the magnetism of these sediments to develop and refine high resolution records of Earth's recent magnetic field behavior and compare them to North Atlantic records. The project will also develop the longest continuous relative paleomagnetic intensity time-series to date back to the earliest Pliocene (~5 million years ago). In addition, these paleomagnetic records will provide a chronological framework for related detailed isotope and climate studies for the region. In terms of broader impacts and outreach, this project will directly support the training and development of a post-doc as the principal investigator and will expose undergraduate students from Oregon State University to basic research methods and concepts. There will be special attention placed on undergraduates being involved in original research, the development of project "ownership" for undergraduate students, and in recruiting a diverse team of researchers.<br/><br/>Paleomagnetic records derived from relatively high sedimentation rate marine cores in the North Atlantic strongly inform and define our current understanding of paleomagnetic secular variation and relative paleointensity (RPI). Replication of records from within this basin argue for RPI variations that have a global expression and reflect stochastic variations in the intensity of the dipolar field. This assumption is likely true, however, it has never explicitly been tested, in part due to a lack of records from different regions of the globe that have a similar resolving ability (i.e. sedimentation rate) to those in the North Atlantic. We will take u-channel samples from the archives halves of U1486 and U1489 and measure the magnetic susceptibility and demagnetization behaviors of the natural remanent magnetization (NRM), anhysteretic remanent magnetization (ARM) and isothermal remanent magnetization (IRM) at centimeter scale. We will use these data to generate characteristic remanent directions and generate estimates of RPI over long Pleistocene and Pliocene timeframes. The 1.25 Myr equatorial Pacific marine sediment record from Site U1486 can be queried for evidence of non-axial-dipole structure and regional heterogeneities at a resolution several times higher than existing records and stacks and is more similar to high quality North Atlantic records. Site U1489 contains a 5 Myr record of sedimentation that will be developed into the longest continuous RPI record ever produced. Preliminary data suggest it is of remarkable fidelity and, when paired with the d18O benthic foraminifer stratigraphy being developed concurrently for this site, can potentially become the type record for Pliocene geomagnetic field behavior. Not only will this record be a magnetostratigraphic tuning target for the Pliocene, it will also inform inquiries into geomagnetic field evolution and organization over the scale of (sub-)orbital variations to full chrons and epochs. RPI-assisted chronologies will be developed for the mid-late Pleistocene records of both U1486 and U1489 (through correlation to existing global stacks) that can then be tandemly tuned with d18O records to develop robust chronologies and the establishment of a strong chronostratigraphic framework to directly facilitate the science objectives of IODP Expedition 363.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Earth's magnetic field is essential for maintaining a planetary atmosphere and for protecting us against harmful cosmic radiation, yet our current understanding of the geomagnetic field and its evolution over thousands to millions of years is still far from complete. To better understand these processes, it is helpful to examine long time series of past magnetic field behavior. Under the right conditions continually accumulating marine sediments can archive near-complete records of relative variations in magnetic field direction and intensity, however, this record is not always simple to decipher, and multiple observations are needed from different parts of the Earth to build confidence in the information we derive from these records.

In November 2016 International Ocean Discovery Program (IODP) Expedition 363 recovered continuous sediment records from two Sites (Sites U1486 and U1489) in the Western Equatorial Pacific, part of a region referred to as the West Pacific Warm Pool. Preliminary magnetic measurements made onboard the D/V JOIDES Resolution suggested that the upper ~95 meters of Site U1486 contained a record of magnetic field variations over the past ~1.5 million years while the upper ~100 meters of Site U1489 contained 17 reversals of the geomagnetic field and preserved a record stretching back ~4.5 million years. In this project we proposed to develop the paleomagnetic records contained within these sediments and resolve information about geomagnetic field direction and geomagnetic relative paleo-intensity (RPI) from an understudied, low latitude, region of the Earth. The magnetic polarity reversals in the record were compared to well-known dates for those field changes to develop age model estimates for the sediments, facilitating Expedition 363 objectives. Development of the RPI record for U1486 enabled comparison to other high-resolution records from the North Atlantic basin, building on our understanding of the global signature of RPI. While the Quaternary record of RPI is generally well understood, Pliocene observations are rare. The 4.5 Myr RPI record from U1489 would be one of the longest, continuous, RPI records ever produced.

Following an intensive u-channel sampling and measurement campaign, the data showed the Site U1489 record to be of remarkable fidelity, reproducing many of the RPI features seen in other records during the Pleistocene (< 2.6 Ma) and established a new view of Pliocene geomagnetic variability back to 4.5 Ma. It has allowed us to interrogate existing lower resolution RPI records that cover parts of the Pliocene to address unanswered questions (often due to a lack of suitable observations) about the behavior of the Earth?s geodynamo. Once coupled with stable isotope measurements being developed by our collaborators a robust chronology will be developed for Site U1489. The RPI record will then be developed into a global, independently dated, RPI tuning target, that extends deep into the Pliocene for the first time. This seminal record has opened the door to establishment of RPI-based chronostratigraphies during the Pliocene and will be especially valuable as an alternative chronostratigraphic tool when trying to date sediments when (for a variety of reasons) stable isotope-based chronologies are not available, e.g., around Antarctica. The Site U1486 paleomagnetic record is of variable quality throughout, but for those intervals that are well preserved, the sedimentary record preserves an excellent quality RPI record, documenting geomagnetic variability at high-resolution from a rare low-latitude perspective. Comparison to and correlation to existing regional records enables the building of Pacific stacks of Brunhes-age (< 0.773 Ma) RPI variability which can then used to evaluate the global nature of RPI over the Brunhes chron. The observations from these two IODP Sites have added valuable spatial and temporal components to our understanding of Plio-Pleistocene geomagnetic field behavior.

In addition to the scientific advancements this proposal was essential in retaining a postdoctoral researcher (Dr. Hatfield) at Oregon State University and then supporting him in a new tenure-track position at the University of Florida. The work completed through this award gave Dr. Hatfield experience in the mentoring of students (both graduate and undergraduate) and it contributed to his professional development in terms of grant management. As one of the largest projects through the Oregon State Paleomagnetic lab at the time, it assisted in the development of large project protocols and data management and workflow techniques. The data from this project has been used directly in the classroom and in class assignments as part of undergraduate and graduate courses at the University of Florida.
